It is wonderful!\n\nI was concerned about all the simmering that someone posted about. So I did a few steps differently:\n\nI buy chicken locally, and the thighs are kind of wimpy. After I boned and skinned the thighs, I soaked them overnight in buttermilk (which I always do with chicken) seasoned with curry powder, salt, and a little sugar.\n\nThe thighs were so thin that I would not have been able to shred them, so I blotted them to get the buttermilk off and cut them into pieces. Then I threw them in with the sautéed vegies (sautéed with both Garam masala and curry powder), added a carton of chicken stock (32 oz.), and simmered with the apples for 10 minutes. I also precooked the basmati rice (I will double the rice next time!), and threw the cooked rice in the pot.\n\nIt was ready to serve, but we like thick soup, so I added some beurre manor to the pot, then served it with a small pitcher of coconut milk that people could add themselves.\n\nOne problem: No one could taste the apples!'}, {'name': 'Joe O ', 'review': 'I am a soup "guy" and this is THE best soup I have ever made. My go to now for pure flavour!'}, {'name': 'Stitch Jones', 'review': "THANK YOU for posting this recipe, my family really enjoyed it & we'll be doubling it from now on so we can enjoy even more of it!\n\n\nMy rice took additional 10 mins to fully cook (perhaps my simmer was lower than yours) and by the end the carrots and celery were mushy and nearly tasteless (they had now been cooked 55-60 mins). \n\n\n\nDo you think it would be ok to add chicken, rice, apples all together in step #2 to reduce total cooking time and maintain the texture of all ingredients?"}]})

Lol'}, {'name': 'Steve Kay', 'review': 'There are as many variations for making matzah brei as there are people who make it. I make it pancake style, for one. I break a single sheet of matzah into small pieces in a bowl, and wet it with cold water. Once it is wet, I squish out as much water as I can. I break a single egg into the moistened matzah and stir it to combine. I might add a pinch of salt. I pour the mixture into a hot buttered 10 inch frying pan and spread it out as thin as I can. The egg and matzah mixture will start to sizzle. When I think the first side is set, generally not more than 2 minutes, I flip it over so the other side can cook. When the other side is done, I will slide it out into the waiting serving plate. Both sides will be slightly browned. I top mine with jam. I make this for breakfast all year long.\nThere is no "wrong" way to make matzah brei, unless you come up with something you don\'t like.'}, {'name': 'flyaway', 'review': 'No onions! Because avocados are similar to eggs in terms of protein and fat content, they work together well. It's a good way to use an avocado that's a little past it's prime, when it starts getting stringy, or not quite ripe and still a little hard, without just making guacamole. I usually use a 4/1 ratio, so 4 eggs to 1 avocado for omelets, or for something like this, 1 egg to 1/4 avocado, and maybe thin it out with a little milk if it's too thick."}]})

Recently, I tried it with bigger macaroni (mentioned above), and while the sauce was exactly right, there wasn\'t enough of it. Can't recommend it highly enough!"}, {'name': 'Lance', 'review': 'I would give 4.5 because the method lacks finesse. \n\nLast night I made the green verde sauce (added a poblano pepper to the recipe along with 4 cloves of garlic). I also roasted the onions and pepper on the sheet pan with the tomatillos. Once done I put it in the fridge for the flavors to meld. This morning I cut the pork into hunks and browned them in my dutch oven. I removed the meat the added the onion and the herbs and let them get somewhat soft and fragrant. I deglazed the pan with homemade chicken stock and then added all of the verde sauce. Putting the meat back into the pan I mixed it around. I had preheated the oven to 350 already. After bringing the sauce and meat to a boil I put the Dutch oven into the oven. After two hours it was perfect. The meat fell apart. I served with homemade flatbread, cabbage slaw and shredded colby-jack cheese. \n\n\nI NEVER just throw a braise into the pot. Browning the meat and then using the fats to release the flavors of the herbs and onions helps layer the flavors.'}, {'name': 'Carla', 'review': "This is a great recipe! My husband and I both love it and so do our friends and family. Sometimes I plan a dinner party just so I can make this dish! It's a good party food since it serves so many, and people enjoy constructing their own tacos when we set up a taco bar. In addition to the cabbage slaw, we include fresh sliced radishes, jalapenos, cilantro, avocados, and Mexican crema. I don't care for cotija cheese, but have used a different soft crumbly cheese that doesn't have the strong flavor. (Sorry, I can't remember the name). I sometimes make cilantro-lime rice to accompany the meal.\nIt's easy to scale up - it seems my local store only sells huge butts! I have found I don't need to double the sauce ingredients though, just need to add enough broth and salsa verde to immerse the pork while simmering. I wondered about the crisping step originally, thinking why bother to crisp it if you're adding the meat back into the sauce and it isn't as crispy after that. But it is definitely worthwhile because it takes the umami flavor even higher - as if it wasn't delicious already! Plus, you get to sample those wonderfully crispy bits right from the baking sheet just to make sure it's good :-). We generally simmer and shred the pork the day before we want to eat it. The next day, we skim some of the fat from the sauce, reduce it, and keep it warm while we crisp the meat. \nIf you don't have enough people to help you eat this (and your store also only sells big butts) you can always freeze the extra carnitas in appropriate sized ziplock bags for future enjoyment - ie. a quick, easy meal where the meat is ready and all you need to do is prep your accompaniments."}, {'name': 'Maggie', 'review': 'Made this today for 4 other friends who came for dinner.The aroma throughout my house while the pork cooked, was putting me in a relaxed, comfortable mood, yet eager to enjoy the finished product.My friends so enjoyed "MY" creative genius (ha, ha). OrderedDict({'page_url': 'https://www.simplyrecipes.com/caldo-verde-recipe-8700874', 'og:title': 'The 3-Step Mediterranean Soup I Make All the Time', 'og:description': 'This classic Portuguese soup is incredibly easy to make. Much of the flavor in caldo verde comes from smoked sausage, with potatoes and kale rounding out the recipe.', 'og:site_name': 'Simply Recipes', 'Title': 'Easy Caldo Verde (Portuguese Kale Soup)', 'Author': 'Sara Haas, RDN, LDN', 'Published Date': 'February 06, 2025', 'Description': 'Easy Caldo Verde (Portuguese Kale Soup) Recipe (6 Ingredients)\nPrep Time: 10 mins; Cook Time: 25 mins; Total Time: 35 mins; Servings: 6 servings', 'Ingredients': '2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil, 8 ounces Spanish\xa0chorizo\xa0or other smoked sausage, cut into 1/4-inch slices, 1 medium yellow onion, chopped, 2 clove garlic, minced, 2 pounds russet potatoes, peeled and cut into 1-inch pieces, 4 cups low-sodium chicken broth, 2 cups water, 1 bunch lacinato (Tuscan) kale, stems removed and leaves thinly sliced, Salt, to taste', 'Nutrition Facts': 'Calories: 402, Fat: 20g, Carbs: 39g, Protein: 17g', 'Reviews': [{'name': 'Paula Bernardes-Silva', 'review': 'Although I&#x27;m delighted to finally see a Portuguese recipe on your site, I&#x27;m also sorry to disappoint you: I don&#x27;t know who gave you this recipe, but that is not caldo verde. 1. The &quot;chouriço&quot;, &quot;linguiça&quot; or even &quot;paio&quot;, if you want it more meaty (these are three types of Portuguese cured sausages, the third one is very large), onion and garlic are not sizzled in the olive oil. 2. The potatoes are completly smashed, not just partially. 3. It definitely is NOT made with chicken broth! 4. It takes a much larger quantity of &quot;couve galega&quot; (collards) ou &quot;couve portuguesa&quot;, which is very similar. The real Portuguese recipe is made like this: In a large pot, you boil the potatoes and the onion (whole, not minced), then make them into a purée. Add salt to taste (pay atention, because the &quot;chouriço&quot; is normally a bit salty) and three or four large (again whole, not minced) garlic cloves and then boil the collards, which must be minced much thinner than you show. When they are almost cooked, add a generous (or not so generous, it&#x27;s up to your taste) extra virgin olive oil portion; make sure the oil boils only for three or four minutes. Than take some bowls (smaller than ramen bowls; the grey one in the photo is the right size) add a slice or two of raw &quot;chouriço&quot; and pour the soup, very hot, on top of it. Accompany it with slices of &quot;broa&quot; (Portuguese corn bread). The only variation allowed is to boil the &quot;chouriço&quot; (yet again, whole, not sliced) with the potatoes and the onions, take it out before you make the purée, and slice it and add to the bowls, as previously said. If you want to see what it looks like, there are photos on Wikipedia (although it also has a mistake, saying we eat it on festivities like weddings and birthdays; not true: we eat it all year round). One thing you got absolutely right, though: it&#x27;s absolutely delicious (and this tradicional version, much healthier)! Oh! And, although we know kale, it&#x27;s something very recent in our country, and we surely don&#x27;t know mustard greens! That being said, I&#x27;m all for creativity in the kitchen. Enjoy!\nP.S. - Sorry for the large comment.'}, {'name': 'Laurel R', 'review': 'Easy and delicious! I used smoked andouille which was tasty, would love to try Spanish chorizo next time. I added a squeeze of lemon at the end and it really brightened up the soup.'}]})

The contributions are boiled ham, pickles, swiss cheese and mustard from the Germans. Salami from the Sicilians and the bread and roast pork from the Cubans. This used to be common knowledge but with the population of Tampa growing the way it has over the last few decades it\'s hard to find many people here that are from here any more so you get these phoney stories made up by people because they sound good.'}, {'name': 'Rosemary Richards', 'review': 'The Cubano originated in Cuba, BUT the Cuban sandwich originated in Tampa to feed the Italian and Cuban immigrants working in the cigar factories'}, {'name': 'kenhowes', 'review': 'The point of the foil is that it will stay warm longer. The dressing should be made by frying the bacon in some olive oil. When the bacon is crisp, crumble it up and then sautee some shallots (or onion) in the bacon, oil, and rendered bacon fat. (The use of the rendered bacon fat is critical as it provides the unctuous texture which elevates the salad.) Add the mustard and vinegar and whisk into a vinaigrette.</p>\n\n<p>The warm bacon vinaigrette gets tossed with the frisee, which will very lightly wilt the lettuce. Then add the warm poached egg on top.</p>\n\n<p>THAT is a salad lyonnaise - a contrast of textures with the warm bacon dressing, barely wilted bitter greens and egg yolk. </p>'}]})

This information allowed me to get the macaroni just how I like it - almost gooey. Recently, I tried it with bigger macaroni (mentioned above), and while the sauce was exactly right, there wasn\'t enough of it. So I upped the cheese powder to 1/4c (4T), the tapioca starch to 3/4 tsp, and used 1 or 2 T of yogurt, whisking the milk (about 1/4 c) in at the end until it was the desired consistency. For bigger macaroni that might be harder to coat, this gives a nice amount of sauce.\nI double this recipe tonight when 2 very picky nephews came over (kids who don\'t even like fruit) (!!!), and they gave it rave reviews, requesting seconds, and calling it "even better than the box." Winner winner cheesy dinner! This is a keeper for sure.'}]})
